posts.cooked:
Hello

I was wondering if  we should always wait a few seconds between powering off and powering on the robot.

I believe with all the sensitive hardware on the robot when we power cycle ( switch off and then switch on) we should wait a few seconds e,g,… switch power off - wait for a few seconds say 3 seconds and then power on.

Instead of …switching off and then immediately switching on the robot.

Curious what other say/do.

posts.name: Nathan Shepherd
posts.cooked: Honestly, I just do this on instinct pretty much everywhere. Those extra few seconds aren’t gonna hurt anyone.
We usually do 5-10 seconds. Hearsay (heardo?) from an experienced electrical mentor. Like @NShep98 just said, it’s not hurting anyone, so why not?

posts.name: Jon Stratis
posts.cooked: Generally speaking with any electronic device, it’s best to wait a few seconds.  You need to allow time for things like  capacitors to discharge, or you can restart it while some parts/chips are still powered.
This makes a lot of sense. Thanks for the reply.

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked: The old FTC control system from Modern Electronics needed like 30+ seconds on power cycle, but I think that is by far the longest cycle in anything I’ve ever seen.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Solution.

Specifically, the time goes up or down based on how long it takes the stored energy to drain through. Motor controllers in particular have large-ish capacitors which have to dump their energy before the bus voltage actually drops low enough to power down electronics.

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: I always count to 5 or something like that. The reality is most likely  you cannot cycle the breaker fast enough to be too fast on an FRC robot. Things with bigger power supplies need more time. Some of them considerable. So it is good to be a little conservative.

posts.name: Galã da Programação
posts.cooked: My team usually power cycle by 5-10 seconds. We never had problems making that way.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
It is good practice to “count to 5” before turning the electronics back on to let the energy storage devices to fully discharge. Some large equipment will need a longer discharge time that is indicated in the instruction manual.

When the system voltage is below what it was intended, the circuitry can get into “unintended states” that are difficult to predict. This can cause seemingly random and possibly dangerous situations.

In reality, most competently designed systems have some sort of system voltage detection that puts the system into a reset state when the system voltage is out of spec and will go to a known safe state, consistently, if the system voltage recovers. This is what is happening when an FRC robot browns out and the Roborio and/or radio reset.
